fname: edesk.com articles setting up chat routing
text: edesk.com articles setting up chat routing .    Setting up Chat Routing | Tiledesk Free Live Chat                    Site preview    Building in progress .. Wait for completion .. Reload    Home Tiledesk Website Community Sign Up     Hi, how can we help?       Home Getting started Getting started for admins Setting up Chat Routing    Setting up Chat Routing   Andrea Leo18 October 2021  The routing default rules are enabled once the project has been created (Note: The default routings rules will be ignored if at least one department exists). You can setting up routing rules by clicking Settings > Routing & Depts in the left panel of the dashboard. To edit your default department, click on the âï¸.   Routing rules Bot Select a bot that responds to visitor requests prior to the agentâs engagement, or by selecting the âbot onlyâ option. With this option the bot will never forword the request to the agent. The agents commitment options are: Assigned Assigned chats help maintain an even workload distribution, especially for larger teams. Chats are evenly automatically assigned amongst all agents or only to those of a group. Pooled Pooled chats give agents more autonomy, allowing them to work at their own pace. With the âPooledâ option, requests are not directly assigned but are listed in the Unassigned conversations list under the Conversations page of the dashboard. Depending on the option chosen, the requests will be displayed by all the agents or by the selected group. For any feedback or issue, feel free to pop in on our Discord channel ð£ For more info on who we are, what we do, or what is our shtick, visit Tiledesk.com ð©âð  Tag:      Admin          chat routing          free live chat          chatbots and humans for customer support          advanced customer service          best zendesk alternative          unlimited free built in chatbots     Share:          Categories   Getting started  Apps and Integrations  Managing Users  Chatbots  Support  Security   Notifications   Troubleshooting  Help Center Guide     Articles in Getting started for admins  Creating a Tiledesk Account  Install widget on your website  How to manage multiple projects  Canned responses in the agent chat  Creating a department  Setting up automatic assignment  Customizing the appearance of the widget  Understanding default roles  Invite the Chatbot when all the agents are offline using Triggers  How do I invite a teammate? text: edesk.com articles configuring push notification in chrome .    How to configure push notification in Chrome | Tiledesk Free Live Chat                   Site preview    Building in progress .. Wait for completion .. Reload    Home Tiledesk Website Community Sign Up     Hi, how can we help?       Home Notifications How to configure push notification in Chrome    How to configure push notification in Chrome   Nicola Lanzilotto14 July 2022  Enable push notifications in Chrome To enable notifications you simply need to: Click on the lock icon (positioned next to the url bar) - a window will pop up.Toggle your notifications on to receive Tiledesk notifications in browser     In the same pop up window, you can toggle your notifications off if you no longer want to receive Tiledesk notifications in browser   Related Chrome push Notifications troubleshooting Not receiving Tiledesk push notifications in Google Chrome Not hearing Tiledesk push notifications in Google Chrome For any feedback or issue, feel free to pop in on our Discord channel ð£ For more info on who we are, edesk.com articles browsing the conversations .    Browsing the conversations | Tiledesk Free Live Chat                    Site preview    Building in progress .. Wait for completion .. Reload    Home Tiledesk Website Community Sign Up     Hi, how can we help?       Home Getting started Getting started for agents Browsing the conversations    Browsing the conversations   Andrea Sponziello19 October 2021  Monitor section: whereabouts & purpose Thanks to the Monitor section, you can see a real-time list of the active conversations of your project. It helps summarize all conversations information at a glance, including information about the visitors, their browser, operating system, location. This section is easy to scan, as it gives you a quick overview of how many users and visitors are waiting for a reply. The conversation list shows you the last message from a customer, how long theyâve been waiting and if the conversation is assigned to an agent or it is unassigned. From the conversations list you can view the following information: Message: the first conversation messageRequester: the visitor informationDepartment: the assigned departmentAssigned to: for the assigned conversations you can view the participating agent (or agents) to the conversationCreated: When the conversation startedActions: Quick actions: Archive Conversation, Join Chat, Open Chat A user with Admin role can view the All Agents Conversations tab where he can view all the project conversations. Otherwise, an agent can see the Your Conversations tab which contain: the conversations where they participatethe conversations of the department to which they belong (if the feature is enabled) View the Assigned Conversations From the Assigned Conversation section you can view the conversations assigned to an agent. If the conversation is assigned to them, the agent can reply to the visitor by clicking the Open Chat button. Handling the Unassigned Conversations You donât need to worry about missing a visitor messages when you are out of the office. With unassigned chats, you can reply any time you want. You can do it anytime you want, no matter if your status is âavailableâ or âunavailable.â Reply to unassigned chats To reply, you need to: Go to Conversations tab, and choose an unassigned chat from the list.Click on Join to Chat the bottom of the page.Click on Open Chat to send your reply like you usually do. An unassigned chat is created when all your agents are offline or you are out of the operating hours. That's all, Tiledesk folks! For any feedback or issue, feel free to pop in on our Discord channel ð£ For more info on who we are, what we do, or what is our shtick, visit Tiledesk.com ð©âð    Tag:      Agent edesk.com articles severity definitions .    Severity definitions | Tiledesk Free Live Chat                   Site preview    Building in progress .. Wait for completion .. Reload    Home Tiledesk Website Community Sign Up     Hi, how can we help?       Home Support Severity definitions    Severity definitions   Andrea Sponziello19 October 2021  Here are the severity definitions that Tiledesk Support uses when prioritizing and working on your issue. If you are able to help us by properly recognizing each severity - for example, by picking Severity One(1) ONLY for your most critical issues - you can be sure that the Tiledesk Support team will address each issue in a timely and efficient manner.  SeverityDefinition1 â Production System DownA Severity One issue indicates the production system is completely shut down or system operations or mission-critical components are down.Tiledesk promptly initiates the following procedures:Assigns specialist(s) to correct the Error on an expedited basis.Provides ongoing communication on the status.Begins to provide a temporary workaround or fix.The assumption is that customer resources are available during the contractual service hours, as necessary, to collaborate on a workaround or fix.     2 â Major ImpactA Severity Two issue indicates the production system is functioning but severely impacted with limited capabilities, or is unstable with major periodic interruptions. A Severity Two issue may also indicate there is a time sensitive question impacting performance or deliverables.Tiledesk assigns a specialist, and provides additional, escalated procedures as determined necessary by Tiledesk Support Services staff. Tiledesk exercises commercially reasonable efforts to provide a workaround or include a fix for the Severity Two issue in the next Service Pack/Maintenance Release.3 â Minor ImpactA Severity Three issue indicates the production system is still functioning but capabilities are moderately impacted, or the system is unstable with minor periodic interruptions or a minor loss of product functionality. A Severity Three issue can also indicate there are errors in system development that may be impacting performance deliverables. There is a medium-to-low impact on your business, but your business continues to function, including by using a procedural workaround.4 â Question â How To â EnhancementA Severity Four issue is a general usage question, request for information, reporting of a documentation error, or recommendation for a future product enhancement or modification. There is low-to-no impact on your business or the performance or functionality of your system. fname: edesk.com articles not receiving tiledesk push notifications in google chrome on mac
text: edesk.com articles not receiving tiledesk push notifications in google chrome on mac .    Not receiving Tiledesk push notifications in Google Chrome (on Mac) | Tiledesk Free Live Chat                   Site preview    Building in progress .. Wait for completion .. Reload    Home Tiledesk Website Community Sign Up     Hi, how can we help?       Home Troubleshooting Not receiving Tiledesk push notifications in Google Chrome (on Mac)    Not receiving Tiledesk push notifications in Google Chrome (on Mac)   Nicola Lanzilotto15 July 2022  Unblock Website Notifications from Chrome's Settings Menu Click the lock icon in the address bar and go to Site Settings:   Then, ensure Notifications is set to 'Allow':   Grant Chrome Notification Permission Launch System Preferences and click Notifications. You'll find two notification instances for Google Chrome in your Mac's Notifications settings. Click each entry and make sure Allow Notifications from Google Chrome is toggled on for both instances.   Disable âDo Not Disturbâ When enabled, 'Do Not Disturb' will pause notifications from Chrome (and other apps) on your Mac. To disable âDo Not Disturbâ, click the Control Center icon in the top-right corner of your Mac's menu bar and toggle off the Do Not Disturb option. Restart and Reset Chrome Closing and relaunching Chrome could also helps eliminate glitches that prevent websites from delivering notifications to your computer. Try that and see if it helps. If you still don't get website notifications on Chrome, despite trying all the solutions recommended above, you might want to reset Chrome's settings.   Reset Chrome's settings Note: Resetting Chrome's settings will revert the browser's theme to factory default and also disable your extensions. Website permissions and cookies will also be removed. Luckily, your browsing history, bookmarks, and saved passwords don't get erased. Open Chrome and click the three-dot Menu button in the upper-right. Choose Settings. Scroll down to the bottom of the Settings page and click Reset settings  Click the  Restore settings to their original default button and you'll see the prompt. Hit the Reset settings button For any feedback or issue, feel free to pop in on our Discord channel ð£ For more info on who we are, what we do, or what is our shtick, visit Tiledesk.com ð©âð  Tag:      on premise alternative Zendesk Intercom          open source software          tiledesk free live chat          notifications troubleshooting          tiledesk notifications          push notifications          notifications     Share:          Categories   Getting started  Apps and Integrations  Managing Users  Chatbots  Support  Security   Notifications   Troubleshooting  Help Center Guide     Articles in Troubleshooting  Not receiving Tiledesk push notifications in Google Chrome (on Mac)  I forgot my password, what now? fname: edesk.com articles install tiledesk on joomla
text: edesk.com articles install tiledesk on joomla .    How to install Tiledesk on Joomla | Tiledesk Free Live Chat                    Site preview    Building in progress .. Wait for completion .. Reload    Home Tiledesk Website Community Sign Up     Hi, how can we help?       Home Apps and Integrations Web Integrations How to install Tiledesk on Joomla    How to install Tiledesk on Joomla   Dario De Pascalis20 September 2022  Find out how to install Tiledesk on your website. You can install it simply by adding the Javascript code to your web page. Follow these quick and easy instructionsâ¦.!!!?? You can add a Tiledesk widget to your Joomla site by adding the chat manually.    To do this, open the console, select the project to integrate, go to settings > installation and select integration with javascript code, now press on copy script to copy the entire code. See the screenshot below. Log in to your Joomla administrator panel.  Go to System >  Templates  > Site Templates section in your Joomla Control Panel. See the screenshot below.    Click on your default theme template.  Open index.php file from the menu on the left side, and paste the JavaScript code, just before the closing </head> tag. See the screenshot below. Remember to press the Save button at the top left of the page to save your changes.Go to your Joomla website  and check if you can see the Tiledesk widget.    Well now Tiledesk is integrated on your fname: edesk.com articles setting up a custom domain for your helpcenter
text: edesk.com articles setting up a custom domain for your helpcenter .    Setting up a Custom Domain for your Help Center | Tiledesk Free Live Chat                    Site preview    Building in progress .. Wait for completion .. Reload    Home Tiledesk Website Community Sign Up     Hi, how can we help?       Home Help Center Guide Customizing your Help Center Setting up a Custom Domain for your Help Center    Setting up a Custom Domain for your Help Center   Andrea Leo22 November 2022  By default, when you Create a New Workspace, a custom url is associated to your Workspace. If you want to know where your Help Center is deployed, click on âSettingsâ on the left sidebar, then expand the Manages Workspace section. In this section, you can manage the current Workspace.     If no Domain is specified, your Help Center will be deployed in: https://help.tiledesk.com/something-like-abc123/ You can change the final part of the path editing the field âCustomize URLâ. Enter your custom domain in Tiledesk Help Center You can choose to deploy your Help Center on your custom domain. To do it you can specify your domain in the âDomain of your Workspaceâ field. If a custom domain is specified, the custom url will be ignored and the Help Center will be no longer available to address https://help.tiledesk.com/something-like-abc123/  How to configure Custom Domain with AWS Create a CloudFront Distribution Sign in to the AWS Management Console and open the CloudFront consoleChoose Create DistributionUpdate the 'Origin' settings. The origin domain will be help.tiledesk.com and the protocol should be HTTPS only. Our servers support TLSv1.2.   Enter under Origin Path field the Tiledesk Help Center path you find under Note section of the next image   leave the other settings as default   Under 'Settings', add your custom domain, e.g. test-customdomain-helpcenter.tiledesk.com as an Alternate domain nameUpload your SSL certificate if you have one otherwise you can use the SSL certificate managed by AWS selecting it from the Custom SSL certificate. You need a certificate that matches your domain. If you use a certificate that does not match your domain, then you will see the following error when navigating to the HTTPS version of your website: NET::ERR_CERT_COMMON_NAME_INVALID     Create a CNAME record Copy your distribution domain nameNavigate to your domain provider and create a new CNAME recordFor host/name input your subdomain (ex help)For value input your CloudFront distribution domain name                Tag:      Custom Domain for your Help Center     Share:          Categories   Getting started  Apps and Integrations  Managing Users  Chatbots  Support  Security Home Getting started Getting started for admins Activities Log    Activities Log   Andrea Leo15 October 2021  Activities: purpose 1.Track Agentsâ Activities The audit log has many benefits: it allows you to securely track what agents have been doing on the system and to keep them accountable for their actions. With the audit log, you can solve potential problems by viewing what has been done on the system by a specific agent at a specific time. 2.Change Activities Tiledeskâs audit log allows you to record all activities performed by agents in the system, ranging from any teammate updates and invitations to new conversations.  3.Add filters for a complete audit log Filters help you narrow down audit log entries and facilitate your search for the information you are interested in. Filters include agent, time period, activities. For example, you may build an audit log that displays activities for a specific time range as well as an individual agent.   That's it for our Activities section! edesk.com articles tiledesk language support .    Tiledesk language support | Tiledesk Free Live Chat                    Site preview    Building in progress .. Wait for completion .. Reload    Home Tiledesk Website Community Sign Up     Hi, how can we help?       Home Getting started Getting started for admins Tiledesk language support    Tiledesk language support   Andrea Sponziello03 February 2022  This article contains the following sections:  Supported user languagesHow to change languageWeb widgetMobile apps Supported user languages  These languages can be selected from the user profile view.  The UI will change to the language selected from the user profile dropdown. Main languages  enEnglishitItaliandeGermanesSpanishptPortuguesefrFrenchruRussiantrTurkisharArabicsvUkrainiansrSerbianzhChinese (beta)svSwedish (beta)uzUzbek (beta)kkKazakh (beta)azAzerbaijani (beta)                                   How to change a language The user can change the default language by clicking on the profile picture in the upper right corner and selecting Edit Profile.  The Edit Profile option gives you a list of personal profile preferences. Scroll down and you will find the Dashboard language settings, with the default option on âAutomaticâ, which is usually English, based not only on the browser settings but also if a specific language is not found among the available one. If you want a specific language among the supported ones please select it from the second option âChoose your preferred languageâ. After selecting your new language, remember to reload the application for the change to take effect. Web widget Widget also automatically selects a language based on the browser settings. Widget comes with the same pre-translated languages of the console application. Pre translated Widget languages are the same of supported languages section Change Widget languages The web widget provides a tool to allow customizing the Widget labels based on your preferences. The Web widget implements the end-user browser language by default, if available. Otherwise it defaults to English. To modify the Web widget âpivotâ language go to Settings > Widget option of the dashboard. Now open the Languages section and click the âAdd languagesâ link, as in the following picture: The Multilanguage window will open (with English as default language): Add a new language To add a new language, stay on the Multilanguage window we just opened. You can add as many languages as you want among the supported ones. Simply click the âAddâ tab button on the top header. A drop down menu will open, where you can choose your preferred language. There are two languages group. Pre-translated and to-be-translated. If you choose one not still translated language we will provide you labels pre-filled with the english translation to help you simplify the label meaning and the translation effort.   The added language appears on the top bar. You can modify all the labels you want. You can also make any language the default one pressing the "MAKE DEFAULT" button. Once you make a language âdefaultâ, it will be automatically selected every time a widget language is not found in the supported languages (those added to the Multilanguage view). Just remember that the âwidget languageâ is the language set in the browser of the end-user, where the widget is loaded and used. In the next Multilanguage window you will be able to change all the labels in the widget for the selected language. Default is English, but you can add new languages. fname: edesk.com articles dialogflow connector handoff to human agent example
text: edesk.com articles dialogflow connector handoff to human agent example .    Dialogflow connector: handoff to human agent example | Tiledesk Free Live Chat                    Site preview    Building in progress .. Wait for completion .. Reload    Home Tiledesk Website Community Sign Up     Hi, how can we help?       Home Chatbots Dialogflow connector Dialogflow connector: handoff to human agent example    Dialogflow connector: handoff to human agent example   Andrea Sponziello20 October 2021  What if, during a conversation with your Dialogflow agent, you want the user to opt for a switch to a human agent? The simplest thing that you can do is adding a specific intent to your Dialogflow agent that will switch to a human agent with a specific instruction in the reply. Train the âtalk to agentâ intent Open your Agentâs Dialogflow console. Add a new intent. Letâs call this intent âTalk to agentâ. Weâll train this intent with a single phrase (more phrases can be added as a convenience). Now the intent will reply with: We are putting you in touch with an operator \agent Copy and paste this text in the Responses section of the âTalk to agentâ intent:   The \agent keyword, at the end of the reply phrase, will never be shown to the enduser. Moreover â\agentâ must be only word on the last line of the reply message. \agent is an instruction for Tiledesk to switch the conversation to humans. As soon as Tiledesk see this instruction in the text it will remove the current chatbot (the Dialogflow agent) from the corresponding conversation and will try to invite a human, following the current department rules. If no agents are available the conversation will wait in the âunservedâ queue until an agent becomes available again. To test the new âTalk to agentâ intent we also place a button under every DF reply (using Microlanguage) to allow the user to ask for an agent after each reply. Letâs train, for instance, the Default Welcome Intent Intent to show this optional button (using Microlanguage you can easily add a button with * symbol (starting a new line) followed by one space and the button text) Hi! How are you doing? * Just questions * Talk to an agent From now on every welcome intent reply the widget will show the âTalk to agentâ button. If we tap the button Talk to agent the corresponding âTalk to agentâ intent will be invoked, the intent reply message is displayed in the conversation and the user will be routed to an agent on the current department (following the department routing rules, opening hours and agents availability). Do you have any feedback on this article? Home Troubleshooting Not hearing Tiledesk push notifications in Firefox    Not hearing Tiledesk push notifications in Firefox   Nicola Lanzilotto15 July 2022  Not receiving audio notifications in Firefox? Open the application menu by clicking the âhamburger buttonâ at the top right of the page. From the menu select Settings > Privacy & Security and then Settings next to Autoplay   Then set the default to 'Allow Audio and Video' or define a custom setting for 'https://console.tiledesk.com/v2/: For any feedback or issue, feel free to pop in on our Discord channel ð£ For more info on who we are, what we do, or what is our shtick, visit Tiledesk.com ð©âð  Tag:      troubleshooting          sound notification     Share:          Categories   Getting started  Apps and Integrations  Managing Users  Chatbots  Support  Security   Notifications   Troubleshooting  Help Center Guide     Articles in Troubleshooting  Not receiving Tiledesk push notifications in Google Chrome (on Mac)  I forgot my password, what now? Reload    Home Tiledesk Website Community Sign Up     Hi, how can we help?       Home Support How to contact the support of Tiledesk    How to contact the support of Tiledesk   Andrea Sponziello19 October 2021  Who to Contact? If you have an issue, where do you go for help? If you are not sure, always log it with support@tiledesk.com. Read also the following detailed guide on what to expect. NOTE: This support mail is valid only for PRO and ENTERPRISE customers. Support Engineers Support Engineers answer questions concerning end-customer environments: Specific functionality (âHow should this button work?â)Broken functionality (âI pressed this button and X should have happened, but I saw Yâ)Broken public API callsInstallation, upgrades, and configuration of Tiledesk product solutions in customer environments All of this is covered by your subscription. Support Case Life Cycle You have contacted support using email support@tiledesk.com. What happens next? Triage Your support case is initially triaged to determine the best Support team to address the question or issue. The Support team collaborates with you to understand the impact this problem is having on your business and to help ensure that we get all the information we need in a timely manner. We then search all available knowledge to see if there is an existing resolution or workaround to your question. Replication attempt If your case identifies a new problem, the support case is assigned to the Support Engineer with the most appropriate knowledge in the pertinent product area. They work your case initially by making every effort to replicate the issue. What happens after the replication attempt depends upon the type and complexity of the stated issue.If a solution is found, we collaborate with you in the most expedient way, ensuring that the support case is updated.If we cannot replicate the issue, we may request your assistance to gather additional detailed information until we are able to replicate and/or resolve the issue. Defect or Enhancement request If we identify the case as a Defect or Enhancement request, a separate issue is logged with Engineering. The Support team assists to prioritize all customer reported issues with Engineering. The issues are then addressed with the items having the greatest impact to customer base taking on the highest priority. The Support team member notifies you of the issue filed with Engineering so that you can monitor the Engineering case as needed. Good communication  Ensuring good communication is important for us to continue to focus on your issue/question. In order for the support team to address your issue/question, we may request additional information. We will expect to receive your responses in a timely manner. In the event that we do not receive a response, then we will follow a case chase sequence where we attempt to contact the customer via the phone. Resolved Normally, a support case is only closed and marked âResolvedâ upon your satisfaction. If the reported issue has not been seen before, the issue and resolution will be documented in the Tiledesk Knowledge Base to assist other customers who may encounter the same issue. Satisfaction survey Your feedback is important to us. As the life cycle last step, you are sent a short survey designed to help us improve our service.  Support channels for FREE customers You can use our Community Forum You can join our Discord server where there is a dedicated channel. This is the invite link More details about our support policies are available on our Developer zone You are welcome to let us know your thoughts or feedback at any time by emailing us at info at(@) Home Apps and Integrations How to connect Tiledesk with Telegram    How to connect Tiledesk with Telegram   Giovanni Troisi18 October 2021  Note: the Telegram integrations is available on the Tiledesk cloud version only. First Login in Tiledesk Dashboard, then click âAppsâ in the left menu and click Install on the Telegram icon. Step 1. Create a Bot Creating a new bot You can create a new bot using Bot Father. Just talk with BotFather (https://telegram.me/botfather) or search for @BotFather in the Telegram app. If you have already created a bot, then copy your telegram token and skip to Step 2. If you have lost the token, then use the /token command and select you bot to retrieve it. Otherwise use the /newbot command to create a new bot. The BotFather will ask you for a name and username, then an authorization token is generated for you. The name of your bot is displayed in the contact details and elsewhere.  The Username is a short name, to be used in mentions and telegram.me links. Usernames are 5-32 characters long and are case insensitive, but may only include Latin characters, number and underscores. Your botâs username must end in âbotâ, e.g. âtetris_botâ or âTetrisBotâ. Step 2. Integration with Tiledesk In your Tiledesk dashboard, enter the Bot Name and paste your Bot Token generated before, then click on âConnectâ button. Step 3. Start messaging from Telegram to Tiledesk Search the bot created with bot name on Telegram. You can send a message from mobile, web or desktop application and get messages on the Tiledesk dashboard. fname: edesk.com articles anonymous vs authenticated users
text: edesk.com articles anonymous vs authenticated users .    How to certify your end-users identity | Tiledesk Free Live Chat                   Site preview    Building in progress .. Wait for completion .. Reload    Home Tiledesk Website Community Sign Up     Hi, how can we help?       Home Managing Users How to certify your end-users identity    How to certify your end-users identity   Andrea Sponziello19 October 2021  How to certify your end-users Every time  an end-user starts a conversation with Tiledesk (generally through our Widget) for the first time, a new Anonymous user is created, by default. This anonymous user has a unique UUID that is reused in next conversations on the same browser instance. Tiledesk creates a Contact for the anonymous-user, if one doesn't already exist, and attaches the new support request to it. With anonymous users, the Agent has no way to certificate the user identity, user email, full name and other data provided by the user. This will prevent the Agent from providing the user with sensitive information. Tiledesk provides a secure way - based on JWT - to provide a certified user profile to Agents. This secure way of providing certified identity is named authenticated visitor and is described here. You can find an example instance of authenticated user in an article (see Â§ Authentication) where we describe what an Italian University did for their live chat project in terms of providing support and sensible information to their own students. As you can see, authenticated users differ from anonymous users by the light blue âshieldâ next to the user profile image: All the details about authentication are always available to Agents in the senderAuthInfo section in the Contact panel and in the Chat side Panel of the current conversation: For any feedback or issue, feel free to pop in on our Discord channel ð£ For more info on who we are, what we do, or what is our shtick, visit Tiledesk.com ð©âð  Tag:      open source lovers          advanced customer service          best zendesk alternative          chatbots and fname: edesk.com articles deploy the help center
text: edesk.com articles deploy the help center .    How to deploy Tiledesk Help Center | Tiledesk Free Live Chat                    Site preview    Building in progress .. Wait for completion .. Reload    Home Tiledesk Website Community Sign Up     Hi, how can we help?       Home Help Center Guide Deploy How to deploy Tiledesk Help Center    How to deploy Tiledesk Help Center   Giovanni Troisi25 August 2022  The Deploy operation allow you to publish your entire Help Center for the first time, or to publish the updates, for example new articles, updated articles, style settings and more. So, until you deploy for the first time, the public Help Center will not exist. As well as, until you do not perform a new deployment, the Help Center will not be affected by new updates. Where your Help Center is deployed By default, when you Create a New Workspace, a custom url is associated to your Workspace. I you want to know where your Help Center is deployed, click on âSettingsâ on the left sidebar, then expand the Manages Workspace section. In this section, you can manage the current Workspace.   If no Domain is specified, your Help Center will be deployed in: https://help.tiledesk.com/something-like-abc123/ You can change the final part of the path editing the field âCustomize URLâ. Deploy on custom domain Alternatively,  following this guide you can choose to Setting up a Custom Domain for your Help Center. Deploy your Help Center As said before all your updates are not visible on your public Help Center until the next Deploy. What is considered âupdateâ? Adding an articleEditing an article (title, body, category, etc.)Moving an article (inside a category or section or between them)Deleting an articleAdding a category/sectionEditing a category/sectionMoving a category/sectionDeleting a category/sectionEditing an authorEditing the workspace setting (style, SEO)Editing the workspace preferences (domain)   To deploy the Help Center click on the âDeployâ green button situated in the top bar. The flashing number represents the number of updates made since the last deployment and which have therefore not yet been published. A popup will remember you where the Help Center will be deployed. Click on the âYes, deploy!â button to proceed.  This operation can take up to a few minutes to be fully performed. When the operation is finished you can click on the âOpenâ button to be redirected to your public Help Center. Enjoy! Please feel free to send feedback about this tutorial to support@tiledesk.com. Thanks! Finally, check our Blog to discover how a chatbot can interact with the knowledge base to automate customer service. fname: edesk.com articles automatically show the assigned agent name after the handoff
text: edesk.com articles automatically show the assigned agent name after the handoff .    Automatically show the assigned agent name after the handoff | Tiledesk Free Live Chat                    Site preview    Building in progress .. Wait for completion .. Reload    Home Tiledesk Website Community Sign Up     Hi, how can we help?       Home Getting started Getting started for admins Automatically show the assigned agent name after the handoff    Automatically show the assigned agent name after the handoff   Andrea Leo05 December 2022  Do you want to discover how to send automatic reply to customer after the conversation is assigned to a live agent? Are you looking to automate repetitive workflows? If the answer is YES, this is the right guide for you. Sometimes you want to show automatically the name (and optionally also the surname) of the current agent who is serving your visitor after an handoff operation, like this: Create a new trigger Let's configure a new trigger following these steps: Go to Settings > Triggers > and click on Add Trigger buttonAdd a trigger nameSelect from the Run trigger events: When a chat message is sent by anyoneAdd the following conditions:Condition 1: Message text, Operator: Contains, Value: âadded to groupâ. With this condition the trigger intercepts the system message sent by Tiledesk when an agent joined the chat. Condition 2: Number of participating bots, Operator: Equals, Value: 0. Add this condition to disable the trigger when a chatbot is serving a chat.As action :Select Send a message to the visitorChoose the message sender from the dropdownInsert a message like this:      Hi I'm {{request.participatingAgents.0.firstname}} {{request.participatingAgents.0.lastname}}. I'm here to help you!!! You can use many variables within the messages sent by triggers. For more variables, see the Request model object   How to send automatic reply to customer after the conversation is assigned to a specific live agent In case you want to to send an automatic reply to your customers and/or website visitors only when the conversation is assigned to a specific live agent you can create exactly the same trigger, but you have to specify the name of the live agent in the message text field, as follows: Please don't forget to select the same live agent for the Send a message to the visitor action in order to provide a good customer experience. Do you want to see the result?  Et voilÃ â¦ Do you like it? If yes and/or you think there is still room for improvement with Tiledesk triggers, please send us a mail to info at (@) tiledesk.com   Do you know that you can also easily integrate Tiledesk to Zapier to automate workflows with other external tools too? This is, for example, the guide about how to integrate Tiledesk with Slack using Zapier.   Finally discover the advantages of automated customer service with Tiledesk. fname: edesk.com articles canned responses in the agent chat
text: edesk.com articles canned responses in the agent chat .    Canned responses in the agent chat | Tiledesk Free Live Chat                    Site preview    Building in progress .. Wait for completion .. Reload    Home Tiledesk Website Community Sign Up     Hi, how can we help?       Home Getting started Getting started for admins Canned responses in the agent chat    Canned responses in the agent chat   Andrea Leo18 October 2021  Canned responses: the purpose Unhappy customer are expensive and time-consuming; quick responses available in your live chat can easily solve this issue and boost your customer satisfaction. We're talking about canned responses that help agents avoid delays and save time by not having to type the same answer over and over again. Canned responses are predefined responses that can be quickly picked from your own pre-made list during the chat. With Tiledesk, you can either type â/â (forward slash) plus a word or the first few letters of any word that is included in the response, or simply click on the âboltâ icon to see the full list of your canned responses. You can even decide to add a new canned response within the chat itself, as per below. Scroll down to learn the complete process of creating, customizing, editing and deleting canned responses.  Creating canned responses Here you can create new canned responses from scratch, edit existing ones, and delete the ones you no longer use. Follow the steps below to add a new one: To begin, go to Settings â Canned responses.Click on âCreate responseâ buttonThen, enter the canned response text.And choose a shortcut title.Click Add this response button to save it Customizing the response You can also create a more engaging experience for your customers by using personalization in your message: 1) When editing a message, you can insert a personalization field by first selecting the area in which youâd like to create the field. 2) Next, click the ADD PERSONALIZATION button 3) Clicking the ADD PERSONALIZATION button will provide a list where you can select which personalization value you would like to add to your message. Editing canned responses Your replies can get old and out of date after some time. You can easily modify them in the following way: First, go to Canned responses.Find the response you want to edit, hover your cursor over it and click edit.Here, you can change the text of the response.And/or its shortcuts title.Click on Save changes to finish up. Deleting canned responses If you no longer need a particular response, you can delete it by following these steps: Go to Settings and click on Canned responses to find the response you want to deleteClick the delete button Do you want to share any sort of comment or feedback with us? Shoot us an email on info@tiledesk.com       Tag:      Admin          canned replies          quick responses in live chat          time saving customer service          open source          chatbots and humans     Share:          Categories   Getting started  Apps and Integrations  Managing Users  Chatbots  Support  Security   Notifications   Troubleshooting  Help Center Guide     Articles in Getting started for admins  Creating a Tiledesk Account  Install widget on your website  How to manage multiple projects  Canned responses in the agent chat  Creating a department  Setting up automatic assignment  Customizing the appearance of the widget  Understanding default roles  Invite the Chatbot when all the agents are offline using Triggers  How do I invite a teammate? Home Troubleshooting Ensure you have the latest Tiledesk version    Ensure you have the latest Tiledesk version   Jovana Ugrinic20 July 2022  How do I know my version of Tiledesk is the latest? Easy peasy.  STEP 1 Scroll down to the bottom of your Dashboard to see what is the current version of Tiledesk you're using. STEP 2 Right-click > choose the last option âInspectionâ, as below STEP 3 Right-click on the button. From the popped up context-menu, choose the third option to empty the cache and refresh (see below): And you're refreshed! Home Notifications Configuring push notification in Firefox    Configuring push notification in Firefox   Nicola Lanzilotto15 July 2022  Enable push notifications in Firefox Launch the Firefox browser app on a mac computer and then: select the Menu icon in the upper-right corner.;choose the Settings option under the Firefox menu;select Privacy & Security in the left pane;scroll down to the Permissions section;Next to Notifications, select Settingsâ¦;uncheck (if checked) the Block new requests to allow notifications check box;select Save Changes.     Related Firefox push Notifications edesk.com articles understanding default roles .    Understanding default roles | Tiledesk Free Live Chat                    Site preview    Building in progress .. Wait for completion .. Reload    Home Tiledesk Website Community Sign Up     Hi, how can we help?       Home Getting started Getting started for admins Understanding default roles    Understanding default roles   Andrea Leo15 October 2021  About Chat default roles Each Tiledesk project includes three roles: Agent, Administrator, and Owner. Each of these roles by default has standard permissions and abilities.  Agents can:   Chat with customersView and manage active or archived chats assigned to them or to the group they belong to (if they belong to a department configured with a group).Add another teammates to a conversation assigned to them or to the group they belong; forward a conversation to another teammateConfigure personal settingsView the contactsCancel the personal account Administrators have all of the default agent privileges. In addition, an administrator can: View all the active and archived chatsArchive all the conversationsConfigure global and personal settingsInvite agentsManage triggers, departments and groupsCreate canned responses and tagsInstall apps from the marketplaceSee the Analytics The owner has all the default administrator and agent privileges. In addition, the account owner can: Upgrade or downgrade the accountâs planDelete permanently chatsDelete permanently contactsChange the teammate roleRemove a teammate from the projectCancel the project account Feel free to reach out to let us know how are you finding Tiledesk on info@tiledesk.com   Tag:      Admin          chat default roles          boost customer satisfaction          chatbots and humans for customer support          open source     Share:          Categories   Getting started  Apps and Integrations  Managing Users  Chatbots  Support  Security   Notifications   Troubleshooting  Help Center Guide     Articles in Getting started for admins  Creating a Tiledesk Account  Install widget on your website  How to manage multiple projects  Canned responses in the agent chat  Creating a department  Setting up automatic assignment  Customizing the appearance of the widget  Understanding default roles  Invite the Chatbot when all the agents are offline using Triggers  How do I invite a teammate? fname: edesk.com articles tiledesk chat right sidebar
text: edesk.com articles tiledesk chat right sidebar .    Tiledesk Free Live Chat â Right sidebar | Tiledesk Free Live Chat                    Site preview    Building in progress .. Wait for completion .. Reload    Home Tiledesk Website Community Sign Up     Hi, how can we help?       Home Getting started Getting started for agents Tiledesk Free Live Chat â Right sidebar    Tiledesk Free Live Chat â Right sidebar   Andrea Leo19 October 2021  Tiledesk chat: whereabouts You'll find your chat section as the very first icon of your dashboard at the left sidebar Once you click on a single conversation, you'll have all of the client's info at a glance on the right side of your screen. Info available about your conversations If you look at the right side of your chat, you'll get all sorts of info about your client, including email, date, geolocation etc. Once the conversation has come to an end, you can easily archive it by using the top button Resolve. If you click on the three dots button, a drop-down menu follows: Reassign: Assign the conversation to another agentAdd teammate: Add an agent to the conversation.Leave: Exit the chat.Open transcript: gives you the entire chat transcript   For any feedback or issue, feel free to pop in on our Discord channel ð£ For more info on who we are, what we do, or what is our shtick, visit Tiledesk.com fname: edesk.com articles creating a tiledesk account
text: edesk.com articles creating a tiledesk account .    Creating a Tiledesk Account | Tiledesk Free Live Chat                    Site preview    Building in progress .. Wait for completion .. Reload    Home Tiledesk Website Community Sign Up     Hi, how can we help?       Home Getting started Getting started for admins Creating a Tiledesk Account    Creating a Tiledesk Account   Andrea Sponziello18 October 2021  Create an account To create a Tiledesk account go to the SIGN UP page and enter the data required for the registration. On your first login, a Setup Wizard opens to help you begin the configuration. Create a project Widget Customization Install Tiledesk widget When you sign up for Tiledesk, you get a 30-day free trial of the Pro plan. After the 30 days, you can choose a paid plan or continue to use Chat for free with the Free FOREVER plan. For details on the plan options, see Tiledesk Chatâs pricing page.      Tag:      Admin     Share:          Categories   Getting started  Apps and Integrations  Managing Users  Chatbots  Support  Security   Notifications   Troubleshooting  Help Center Guide     Articles in Getting started for admins  Creating a Tiledesk Account  Install widget on your website  How to manage multiple projects  Canned responses in the agent chat  Creating a department  Setting up automatic assignment  Customizing the appearance of the widget  Understanding default roles  Invite the Chatbot when all the agents are offline using Triggers  How do I invite a teammate? Reload    Home Tiledesk Website Community Sign Up     Hi, how can we help?       Home Support Service Level Targets (SLTs)    Service Level Targets (SLTs)   Andrea Sponziello19 October 2021      Application Service Level targets refer to both Cloud and On-premise installations in relation to the Enterprise Plan. For the period in which all payments have been made correctly and the Company remains fully in agreement with the Terms and Conditions, Tiledesk will make all reasonable efforts to provide the necessary support.â The Company agrees to send his support requests to Tiledesk through the tools prepared and communicated in the purchase order. Requests outside the channels indicated in the order will not be taken into consideration.â Intervention times always depend on the extent of the problem encountered and are shown below.  How does the support work? Tiledesk will make every reasonable effort to ensure maximum availability of the self-hosted installation infrastructure.â Below are the target response times for a support case based on the customerâs Enterprise Plan type and support case severity level. SeverityShort titleResponse timeOne (1)Production System Down2 Business hoursTwo (2)Production/Development â Major Impact4 Business hoursThree (3)Production/Development â Minor Impact1 Business dayFour (4)Question/How-to/Enhancement2 Business day Subsequent Service Level Target Response Times SeverityShort titleResponse timeOne (1)Production System DownBusiness hourlyTwo (2)Production/Development â Major ImpactEvery two business daysThree (3)Production/Development â Minor ImpactEvery three business daysFour (4)Question/How-to/EnhancementEvery five business days Do you have a doubt about the severity of your case? Check our severity definitions.    Tag:      Service Level Targets          open source live chat          open source chabot builder     Share:          Categories   Getting started  Apps and fname: edesk.com articles configure a whatsapp business account
text: edesk.com articles configure a whatsapp business account .    How to configure a WhatsApp Business account | Tiledesk Free Live Chat                    Site preview    Building in progress .. Wait for completion .. Reload    Home Tiledesk Website Community Sign Up     Hi, how can we help?       Home Apps and Integrations WhatsApp Business How to configure a WhatsApp Business account    How to configure a WhatsApp Business account   Giovanni Troisi02 September 2022  Tiledesk WhatsApp Integration allows your customers to reach you through their favourite messaging application: WhatsApp. On the other end, your agents will be able to promptly respond directly from our Web Chat. Quick replies, action buttons and media like images, videos and documents are supported on both sides. But first, you need to create and configure a WhatsApp Business account. Keep reading to find out everything you need. Create app on Facebook Developer console If you have already created an app, you can skip this step. Otherwise, go to Meta for Developers and sign in with you Facebook credentials, where you can see your Facebook apps. Then click on "My Apps", and on "Create App", as below. Select an app type and click on âNextâ. Now choose the display name and type the contact email. Note: a Business Account is required to have access to all features and to allow certain permissions. You can create an account for your company from the dedicated tool or by continuing to read this guide. If you already have a Business Account, select it and click on âCreate appâ. If you don't, not to worry, you can create a Business Account later. Well done! Your app is now ready. Integrate WhatsApp with your app. When on the same Facebook Developer console, make sure that you have selected the app where you want to install WhatsApp and search âWhatsApp" from the products list, then click âSet upâ. You should be able to see that on the left-side bar. Click on âGetting Startedâ. If you've selected a Business Account in the previous step, you can skip the steps below, otherwise keep reading! Create a Business Account After clicking on âGetting Startedâ you will see the tool for selecting or creating a business account. Select âCreate a business accountâ from the dropdown menu and click âContinueâ. A default Business Account has been created. You can customize this account accessing the Meta Dashboard or clicking on Test Business in MyApp page, as below.   Test the integration A Test Number is now associated with your app. Further down this article we will see how to setup the company's real number.  From the Getting Started tab you can test the WhatsApp integration, but first you need to configure a receiver number. In this testing phase, you can send a message from the test number to up to 5 phone numbers to receive free test messages. To configure a test phone number click on the âToâ dropdown, and then on âManage phone number listâ button. Select the prefix and insert the phone number, then start the verifying procedure by clicking on "Next" (a numeric code is sent by SMS). Once completed, the phone number can receive test messages. Click on âSend Messageâ button to try it out. You should receive a message on WhatsApp from the test number. Add a production phone number You may need to register a company production phone number. Use of a private number is highly discouraged. You won't be able to use the WhatsApp mobile app anymore. From the Getting Started page, click on âAdd phone numberâ, as below. Fill in your business information and click on âNextâ. Fill in the required information to create a WhatsApp Business profile and click on âNextâ. Finally, add the phone number and verify it through a Text message or Phone call. Note: If you are using a landline number, you can verify the number only with a Phone call. Once the number has been approved, you can test it, as shown earlier in this guide, by selecting the production number from the âFromâ dropdown. Configure a Permanent Access Token To use the WhatsApp integration with Tiledesk you need a valid access token. A Temporary access token is provided, but you need to refresh the information every 24 hours. This is a good solution for a testing phase, but you need a Permanent access token in production. Let's see how to create a Permanent Accesso Token! Click on the name of the Business Account in My Apps or go directly in Facebook Settings Dashboard from the Facebook Developer dashboard. On the left-side panel, make sure that Business Account for which you want to activate the permanent token is selected, click on âSystem usersâ and then click the âAddâ button. Type a System user name and choose Admin role. Now you can click on the âCreate system userâ button. A user system has now been created. Note that the permanent token will be associated to that user. Let's add assets to the newly created system user by clicking on âAdd Assetsâ and giving the Full Control to the Facebook App, as illustrated below. Click on âSave Changesâ and the app will be added to the system user. Finally, we are ready to generate our Permanent Access Token by clicking on âGenerate new tokenâ. Select the appâ¦ â¦ and check the following permissions: whatsapp_business_messagingwhatsapp_business_management Click on âGenerate tokenâ and that's it! Your permanent token is now available.   Don't know how to use the permanent token on Tiledesk? Maybe the guide on How to connect WhatsApp Business to Tiledesk might be helpful.   If you have any questions, feel free to contact us live on chat or at support@tiledesk.com or you can pop on our Discord Channel ð£. For more info on who we are, what we do, or what is our shtick, visit the Tiledesk Website ð©âð. edesk.com articles containerization support policy .    Containerization Support Policy | Tiledesk Free Live Chat                   Site preview    Building in progress .. Wait for completion .. Reload    Home Tiledesk Website Community Sign Up     Hi, how can we help?       Home Support Containerization Support Policy    Containerization Support Policy   Andrea Sponziello19 October 2021  Deployment Tiledesk supports deployment using the open industry-standard technology Docker for containerization and Kubernetes for orchestration. We provide reference Docker images and a reference orchestrated deployment using Kubernetes and Helm. These deployment templates are there to enable customers to understand the best practices for deployment of our platform. As with traditional on premise deployment methods, customers may wish to customize or build upon the technology and ideas within our deployment templates. The deployment templates provide a starting point for customers to simplify the creation of deployments unique to their own needs and skill sets. Where customers make this kind of customization, Tiledesk will support the underlying images, providing they are using the supported infrastructure components listed on our product supported stack configurations. The above illustration shows four deployment options, Tiledesk creates and supports only the software represented as App1, App2, and App3. Tiledesk doesnât create or support anything else in the diagram â thatâs all considered to be âinfrastructureâ. There are different ways to deploy Tiledesk software into an infrastructure before it can run. A few options include using custom shell scripts, installers, Docker Compose, Kubernetes, Docker Enterprise, OpenShift, Heroku, Google Cloud, AWS ECS, AWS EKS and so on. Tiledesk doesnât create or support any deployment tool and customers may choose the deployment tool they feel most comfortable with, often this will be based on a company standard. Customers must have the skills and knowledge needed to use their chosen deployment tool effectively. Tiledesk cannot provide assistance on the deployment tool/mechanism, our approach is to support industry-leading standards and best practices to give customers the choice of platforms on which to deploy. Tiledesk aims to update the reference Docker images as the underlying operating system and libraries are released, however, as weâre building upon the work of others, we cannot give guarantees and assurances on the timeliness of upgrades and patches for security issues as we would for our own software. Finally, let us share the quick guides to deploy Tiledesk open source live chat + chatbot builder: Deploying Tiledesk Community using Docker Compose Install Tiledesk with Kubernetes and Helm If instead you are interested to our Software-as-a-Service distribution you can check our pricing options to find the one that suits best your needs. edesk.com articles chatbot directives .    Chatbot Directives | Tiledesk Free Live Chat                    Site preview    Building in progress .. Wait for completion .. Reload    Home Tiledesk Website Community Sign Up     Hi, how can we help?       Home Chatbots Tilebot Chatbot Directives    Chatbot Directives   Andrea Sponziello07 September 2022  Chatbot directives are the way Tiledesk supports - with simple commands - chatbots orchestration with other chatbots, Tiledesk Apps and Tiledesk APIs. Directives can be placed at the end of an intent reply. In this way the intent match will also executes the commands. Directives are case insensitive. This measn that you can write \agent or \Agent. Both commands executes the same directive. Mixing directives  Directives can be mixed. When mixed, directives are executed in sequence. The next directive is executed when the first one ends. You can use this directives' property to create useful mixin. For example when moving to a department with a chatbot you would like the chatbot to send his welcome message. You can simply create a commands' chain like in the following example where you concatenate a \hmessage that sends the hidden "start" text to trigger the chatbot welcome message of the Default department.. Moving you to Sales team... Our working hours are 9:00-18:00 (GMT+2) \_tddepartment sales \_tdhmessage start Another useful case is when you want send multiple messages with just one intent reply. You can reach this goal mixin the \message and the \wait directives in sequence, like in the following example: \_tdmessage Good morning \_tdwait \_tdmessage May the Force be with you today \_tdwait \_tdmessage ð Getting this: Discover all Directives   \_tdAgent Invite an agent in the conversation using department rules Example: Moving you to an agent... \_tdAgent   \_tdWhenOnlineMoveToAgent It works like \agent but it invites an agent only if in online hours. Example Moving you to an agent \_tdWhenOnlineMoveToAgent   \_tdClose Closes a conversation. Bye \_tdClose   \_tdDepartment Changes the current conversation department \_tddepartment DEPNAME|DEPID If DEPNAME is not specified it moves to the Default Department Example 1 - Moves to root (Default) Department: \_tddepartment Example 2: In the following example \_tdhmessage is optional, it sends the hidden "start" text to trigger the chatbot welcome message of the Default department. If the chatbot is availble it will send the âstartâ intent message in the conversation. Moving you to Sales team... Our working hours are 9:00-18:00 (GMT+2) \_tddepartment sales \_tdhmessage start   \_tdWhenOfflineHours During offline hours this directive adds (or replace) a custom message to the intent reply, showing that no human operators are available to serve the request. Options --message -m A comma delimited message that will be shown to the end user --replace -r This flag indicates to entirely replace the intent message with the offline message Example 1: Hello Please choose an option to continue * I forgot my password * Discover directives > https://gethelp.tiledesk.com/articles/chatbot-directives/ * Talk to an agent \_tdwhenofflinehours -m "**We are closed** ð" And when in offline hours you will see the bold message on top of the welcome message: Example 2 - Replace the whole message with the offline message: Hello Please choose an option to continue * I forgot my password * Discover directives > https://gethelp.tiledesk.com/articles/chatbot-directives/ * Talk to an agent \_tdwhenofflinehours -m "**We are closed** ð" --replace   \_tdReplaceBot Use this directive to replace the current conversation chabtot with the specified one. If no chatbots are in the conversation the new one will be added. Usage: \_tdreplacebot chatbotName chatbotName is mandatory. Example: Hello. We are moving you to the Sales chatbot... \_tdreplacebot salesBot \_tdhmessage welcome In the previuos example we use the \_tdreplacebot directive to move to the salesBot. Then we send the âwelcomeâ hidden message to trigger the bot greeting message.   \_tdDeflectToHelpcenter You can use this directive to automatically deflect a fallback reply to a search in the Help center workspace. This directive automatically triggers an help center search into the specified workspace. The keywords used for the search are extracted from the end-user question. The directive displays one or more results as link buttons, up to 3 and only if results are found. No button is shown if no results are found. Options --message -m A comma delimited message that will be shown to the end user in place of the original chatbot reply --workspace -w This flag indicates to use the specified workspace for the search. The search defaults to the first workspace found, so if you have only one workspace there is no need to specify this option. Example: In this case the directive is added to the default fallback intent of the chatbot. Every time the default fallack is matched the directive is triggered. I'm sorry but I can not provide an adequate answer Please rephrase your question \_tdDeflectToHelpCenter -m "I wasn't trained for that but...I found something interesting in our Knowledge base ð" The user is asking for âis dialogflow supported?â. The chatbot is not trained to reply and deflect to the default fallback intent. The DeflectToHelpcenter directive is triggered, it finds three results. The directive also replaces the original intent reply with his own special reply, indicating that something in the Knowledge base was found. The link buttons automatically open the results in the widget in self mode.    \_tdMessage Use this directive to send a message back to the conversation. This is useful whenever you want to send a message mixed with other directives (i.e. after a directive to replace the current bot - \_tdreplacebot - or to change the current conversation's department - \_tddepartment). Usage: \_tdmessage message Example (in combination with \_tdwait): \_tdmessage Good morning \_tdwait \_tdmessage How are you today?   \tdHMessage Use this directive to send a hidden message back to the conversation. With this diretive you can to send a hidden message into the conversation to trigger some reply message back from the chatbot (i.e. after replacing/adding a current bot to trigger the greeting message). Usage: \_tdhmessage message Example (in combination with \_tdreplacebot): We are moving you to the Sales bot... \_tdreplacebot salesBot \_tdhmessage start   \_tdWait Use this directive to wait a certain amount of time before the next directive to be executed. Usage: \_tdwait milliseconds milliseconds - the amount of time in milliseconds. Must be greater then 500 and less then 10.000. It defaults to 1.000 milliseconds (1 second). Example (in combination with \_tdmessage) - Sending multiple messages. The first second message after the default _tdwait delay of one second (no delay is specified), the last message after 2 seconds delay. \_tdmessage Good morning \_tdwait \_tdmessage May the Force be with you today \_tdwait 2000 \_tdmessage ð   \_tdIntent Use this directive to directly invoke a specific intent. Arguments The intent name to invoke Usage: \_tdintent Intent Name Example 1 - Reuse of intents: In this example you can reuse an Intent (that's a simple menu), in common with many intents, to increase the logic reuse. I'm sorry but there are no agents available... You can anyway choose your topic to be later contacted by an agent. \_tdintent menu Example 2 In this example you can use the _tdintent in combination with conditional logic, to reply/execute specific intents based on some conditions: Evaluating conditional flow... \_tdIfNoAgents \_tdintent no_agents_available \_tdIfAgents \_tdintent agents_available \_tdWhenClosed \_tdintent weareclosed  \_tdIfNoAgents Use this directive to execute conditional logic only when, during operating hours, no agents are available. The directive doesn't execute any logic when the condition is not met. Arguments The directive to invoke. Usage: \_tdIfNoAgents Directive Example: In this example you will invoke an intent only when the condition applies \_tdIfNoAgents \_tdintent no_agents_available   \_tdIfAgents Use this directive to execute conditional logic only when, during operating hours, at least one agent is available. The directive doesn't execute any logic when the condition is not met. Arguments The directive to invoke. Usage: \_tdIfAgents Directive Example: In this example you will invoke an intent only when the condition applies \_tdIfAgents \_tdintent agents_available   \_tdWhenOpen Use this directive to execute conditional logic only during operating hours. The directive doesn't execute any logic when the condition is not met. Arguments The directive to invoke. Usage: \_tdWhenOpen Directive Example: \_tdWhenOpen \_tdintent we_are_open   \_tdWhenClosed Use this directive to execute conditional logic only outside of operating hours. The directive doesn't execute any logic when the condition is not met. Arguments The directive to invoke. Usage: \_tdWhenClosed Directive Example: \_tdWhenClosed \_tdintent we_are_closed   \_tdSendEmail You can use this directive to automatically send an email to someone as an action after an intent invokation. This directive is very useful if you want for example to send an email as soon a new lead compiles a form or whenever the end-user terminate a list of questions. Options --to A list of comma delimited email addresses --subject The email subject. --text The email text message Example: In this case the email notification is added as soon as a new lead terminates to compile an intent's form We got your data ${userFullname} \_tdsendemail --to "${agentEmail}" --subject "New lead!" --text "You got a new lead ð His name ${userFullname} lead email ${userEmail} By Tiledesk Team"   Examples Combining conditional logic directives: It's easy, during chatbot design, to encounter this significant use case: You want different messages/logic to be executed when meeting some of the following conditions: You are in online-hours but no agent is avaibleYou are in online-hourse and at least one agent is availableYou are in offline-hours You can use the previous conditional logic combined to execute different actions, as in the following example: Checking available agents... \_tdIfNoAgents \_tdintent no_agents_available \_tdIfAgents \_tdintent agents_available \_tdWhenClosed \_tdintent weareclosed                          Tag:      open source chatbot builder          no code low code          conversational design          open source Reload    Home Tiledesk Website Community Sign Up     Hi, how can we help?       Home Chatbots Tilebot Tiledesk Chatbot Forms    Tiledesk Chatbot Forms   Andrea Sponziello30 November 2022  In this article you will learn everything you need about Tiledesk Chatbot Forms Tiledesk chatbot Forms are a way to collect data from the users in a structured way. Sometimes getting on an intent is not enough for the intent itself. Suppose for example that, before welcoming a new user, your chatbot wants to know his name. So he can greet something like: âHi Andrea, how are you today?â. What would you like to achieve is submitting the user a very short greet message, then asking him âCan you tell me your name?â, and then, finally, greet him by name. Lets's start by this example Basic concepts: Greet a user by name Once you create your intent you must move to the From section and press the Add Form button: Select âCustomâ Fill out the Variable name (=userName), Type (=Text) and the Label value (=The question we use to ask the user to reply with his name) Press Add to add the field. You wil see the newly created field in the fields form list: To complete the steps we can already use the provided variable (userName) in the Intent Answer section as in the following figure. Note that to use the variable we can simply sorround it with a $ sign followed by a couple of brackets: Use variable template syntax:  ${variableName} Lets' save the intent. And try it out (Test it button on top right corner) As you can see we used the userFullname variable from the form to greet the user. Keep in mind that the variable will be available for all the conversation lifetime. Some special variables are instead available and shared throughout all the user interaction lifetime, also cross-conversations. They are called Reserved variables. Reserved variables Here follows a list of the main reserved variables: userFullname: it is the user fullname that Tiledesk will use to recognize the end-user userEmail: it is the email that Tiledesk will use to interact with the end-user We'll understand how to use the above reserved variable names in the next example Advanced example - Reserved variables In this example we'll learn how to get the userName and userFullname while building a lead acquisition data during a conversation.      Tag:      chatbot          forms          chatbot forms          tiledesk forms          chatbot input fname: edesk.com articles how to create a stripe payment directly from the chat
text: edesk.com articles how to create a stripe payment directly from the chat .    How to create a Stripe payment directly from the chat | Tiledesk Free Live Chat                    Site preview    Building in progress .. Wait for completion .. Reload    Home Tiledesk Website Community Sign Up     Hi, how can we help?       Home Apps and Integrations Stripe payment How to create a Stripe payment directly from the chat    How to create a Stripe payment directly from the chat   Mirco Leo16 January 2023  Before starting to use the App it is necessary to configure it with the Stripe parameters of your organization. To configure the App follow the following article Connect Tiledesk with your Stripe account. The Agent can create a payment intention for the Customer he is chatting with in Tiledesk quickly through the App. The payment intent will be created on the Stripe platform thanks to the integration between Tiledesk and the Stripe payment platform. To create a payment for your Customer, the Agent must select the conversation in the Chat section .. .. and click on the App button at the bottom right.  The App will open on the right of the screen. The home page allows you to create a new payment or configure the App with the Stripe platform integration parameters. To configure the App follow the following article Connect Tiledesk with your Stripe account. To create a new payment, the Agent must click on the Create a payment button. Now the agent has to enter the parameters of the payment intent that he wants to create on the Stripe platform for his Customer. The mandatory parameters to create a new payment are the customer's email, the currency and the payment amount. As soon as the Agent enters the parameters, he can click the Create Payment button to create the payment intention on the Stripe platform and send it directly in the  The Customer receives a form to proceed with the payment directly in the chat during the conversation with the A Now the Customer can enter his card details and make the payment without ever leaving the chat with the Agent.gent. Now the Customer can enter his card details and make the payment without ever leaving the chat with the Agent :-)!!! The Agent can support the Customer during the payment on the chat by providing all the information necessary to complete the procedure. Insert the Card number, Expiration data, CVC and Country to make the payment it is necessary to click on the Pay now button.   The system replies directly on the chat informing the Customer and the Agent that the payment has been made correctly on the Stripe platform. Furthermore, the payment made by the Customer is also visible on the Stripe payment platform.      Tag:      Payment on Stripe          Open Source Lovers          Boost Customer Service fname: edesk.com articles handoff to human agents
text: edesk.com articles handoff to human agents .    How to transfer my chatbot to a live agent | Tiledesk Free Live Chat                    Site preview    Building in progress .. Wait for completion .. Reload    Home Tiledesk Website Community Sign Up     Hi, how can we help?       Home Chatbots Tilebot How to transfer my chatbot to a live agent    How to transfer my chatbot to a live agent   Andrea Sponziello19 October 2021  What if, during a conversation you want a chatbot-human handoff? Chatbot-human handoff is when you are transferring the conversation from a chatbot to a live agent. The simplest thing that you can do is adding a specific answer to your Response bot that will switch to a live or human agent with a specific instruction in the reply.  Train the âtalk to agentâ intent  Open your Response bot console. Add a new Question/Answer. Letâs call this intent âTalk to agentâ. Weâll train this intent with a single phrase (more phrases can be added as a convenience). Now the intent will reply with: We are putting you in touch with an operator \agent Copy and paste this text in the Responses section of the âTalk to agentâ intent: The \agent keyword, at the end of the reply phrase, will never be shown to the enduser. It is an instruction for Tiledesk to switch the conversation to humans. As soon as Tiledesk see this instruction in the text it will remove the current chatbot (your chatbot) from the corresponding conversation and will try to invite a human, following the current department rules. If no agents are available the conversation will wait in the âunservedâ queue until an agent becomes available again. To test the new âTalk to agentâ intent we also place a button under every question (using Microlanguage) to allow the user to ask for an agent after each reply. Letâs train, for instance, the Default Welcome Intent Intent to show this optional button (using Microlanguage you can easily add a button with * symbol (starting a new line) followed by one space and the button text) Hi! How are you doing?  * Just questions  * Talk to an agent From now on every welcome intent reply the widget will show the âTalk to agentâ button. If we tap the button the âTalk to agentâ intent will be invoked and the user will be routed to an agent on the current department (following the department routing rules, opening hours and agents availability). Do you have any feedback on this article? Please send us your feedback writing an email to info@tiledesk.com Enjoy Tiledesk!
